question_text: What broad prehistoric period, lasting roughly 3.4 million years and divided into the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic sub-periods, is defined by the widespread use of stone to make tools?
What type of prehistoric parietal art, found on the walls and ceilings of sites such as Lascaux and Altamira, most commonly depicts large wild animals like bison, horses, and aurochs?
distractors: Petroglyphs carved into open-air rock faces

question_text: What term refers to the prolonged geological periods of extensive glaciation during which, at maximum extent, approximately 30 percent of the Earth's surface was covered by ice sheets?
Which prehistoric megalithic monument on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England, features an outer ring of sarsen standing stones topped by lintels and inner bluestones transported from South Wales?
What genus of extinct elephantids, whose last isolated population survived on Wrangel Island until approximately 4,000 years ago, is one of the most iconic examples of Pleistocene megafauna?
Fossils of which group of animals, the dominant terrestrial vertebrates of the Mesozoic Era from roughly 252 to 66 million years ago, are among the most recognized artifacts of deep time?

What extinct hominin species, classified as Homo neanderthalensis, inhabited Europe and Western Asia until roughly 40,000 years ago and contributed approximately 2 percent of the DNA in modern non-African human populations?
What archaeological period, beginning around 3500 BCE in western Eurasia, is defined by societies that produced or traded tools and weapons made from an alloy of copper and tin?
What period in human history, beginning between 1200 and 600 BCE depending on the region, is defined by the mass production of tools and weapons from smelted iron and steel rather than bronze?

What term describes a body preserved after death, either intentionally through embalming techniques — as practiced in ancient Egypt beginning around 2600 BCE — or accidentally through natural environmental conditions?
